div.p: N78/8938, unit 1050, VPRS 3991/P inward registered correspondence, VA 475 Chief Secretary's Department, Public Record Office, Victoria.

To proof.
See also M to W. Odgers, 27 September 1877. Melbourne

In compliance with your request
On 1 July 1878 A. Hume, Secretary to the Government of India, Department of Revenue, Agriculture and Commerce, Simla wrote to the Chief Secretary, G. Berry: 'The Director of the Botanical Gardens at Melbourne [i.e. W. Guilfoyle] having lately offered to supply the Government of India with seeds and plants, I am directed to state that the Governor General in Council will be glad if His Excellency the Governor will cause the following seeds to be supplied, in case they can conveniently be obtained: Acacia
melanoxylon — 10lbs | Acacia
dealbata — 15 " | Acacia
decurrens — 10 " | Acacia homalophylla — 5lbs | Total 40lbs | 2 Any outlay incurred on this account will be gladly refunded by the Government of India.' (N78/8413, unit 1050, VPRS 3991/P, PROV).
On 14 August Odgers minuted to the Minister of Lands, Francis Longmore, the Minister responsible for the Botanic Garden, that 'it is irregular for a subordinate officer to communicate with another Govt. Such correspondence is conducted by the Hn. the Chief Secretary. This dept will supply the seeds asked for.' This minute was forwarded to Guilfoyle on 15 August and duly 'noted' by him.
On 22 August 1878 Odgers minuted: 'Will Gov. Botanist be so good as to obtain and have packed for transmission the seeds required'. M marked the file on 26 August: 'Seeds provided herewith according to request'. I have the honor of forwarding herewith the following seeds, as ordered for the Government of India

The seeds are fresh, of the last seasons gathering. I have been unable to secure the 5 lb of Acacia homalophylla, as the seed of this tree (the Myall-tree) is never regularly collected for the trade;
The seeds … trade is marked with a line in the margin.
moreover it cannot be obtained nearer than the Murray-River, and even there the tree has become very scarce. No new Myall-seeds can be got before January; I will endeavour to procure these particular seeds then.
On 13 September Odgers minuted: 'It is noticed that in the a/c passed in favour of the Government Botanist no claim is made for seeds Will the Baron von Mueller be so good as to state whether he was unable to obtain the seeds, or if it escaped his attention'. This minute was referred to M the same day and he returned it on 16 September.
On 21 September G. Berry wrote to A. Hume to advise the despatch of a parcel containing Eucalyptus seed and requesting a remittance of £13.18.0 on account of their cost and freight. Hume replied on 16 November acknowledging receipt of the seed and advising that instructions for payment had been issued (P79/67, unit 1050, VPRS 3991/P, PROV). The Comptroller General, Calcutta, also wrote to Berry on 16 November enclosing a Bill of Exchange for the amount owing and asked for its receipt to be acknowledged. A letter of acknowledgement was sent to him on 10 January 1879 (P79/132, unit 1050, VPRS 3991/P, PROV).
